See a 157-Year-Old Great Lakes Shipwreck in Stunning Detail With This New 3D Scan
Last year, maritime archaeologists revisited the â€œNorthernerâ€ in Lake Michigan and captured hundreds of still images, which they stitched together to create a digital replica of the vessel
On November 28, 1868, an American schooner called the Northerner was loading up with cargo near Cedar Grove, Wisconsin, when its hull became badly damaged. The next day, while being towed to Milwaukee for repairs, the vessel filled with water and sank to the bottom of Lake Michigan. The shipâ€™s crew members were rescued, but the vessel was never recovered.
Now, 157 years later, experts have produced a highly detailed 3D digital scan that gives users a chance to virtually explore the shipwreck as it rests on the lakebed. Created by stitching together 1,670 still images, the replica even shows the Northernerâ€™s final load of cordwood still in its hull.
The 81.1-foot-long vessel was built in Clayton, New York, in 1850 by John Oades, one of the most experienced shipbuilders on the lakes at the time. The ship initially set sail on Lake Ontario, ferrying supplies to communities on the American and Canadian shores. Later in her career, the ship transported lumber on Lake Michigan.
It was during one of those lumber-carrying missions that the vessel endured irreparable damage. While loading up with cordwood at Amsterdam, the vessel â€œpounded heavily upon the bottomâ€ at the pier, according to a November 1868 Milwaukee Sentinel report shared by the Wisconsin Shipwrecks database.
The ship was leaking badly, so the captain navigated south to Port Washington and unloaded the cargo that was being stored on the deck. However, his efforts proved futile. While being towed by another vessel, the Cuyahoga, the ship filled with water and capsized near Port Ulao, a historic port located roughly 20 miles north of Milwaukee.
The shipwreck was initially discovered by divers in the early 1970s. But it wasnâ€™t until 2009 that the Wisconsin Historical Societyâ€™s Maritime Preservation and Archaeology Program officially recorded its location. In 2010, it was listed on the National Register of Historic Places, and in 2021 it became part of the newly designated Wisconsin Shipwreck Coast National Marine Sanctuary.
Today, the vessel is still largely intact. It rests upright, submerged roughly 135 feet deep, making it a popular destination for recreational scuba divers. In 2024, crews installed buoys and mooring lines near 19 of the most popular shipwrecks at the sanctuaryâ€”including the Northernerâ€”to make the sites easier to locate and safer to dive. The permanent mooring system also helps protect the lakebed from damage caused by anchors and grappling hooks, since they give dive boats a place to tie up.
Last year, maritime archaeologists and engineers embarked on a weeklong expedition to survey some of the Great Lakesâ€™ deepest wrecks, many of which are rapidly deteriorating because of invasive quagga mussels. Their first stop was the relatively shallow Northerner, where they tested out an autonomous underwater vehicle equipped with high-tech underwater imaging instruments.
Using the Saab Sabertooth robot, they captured highly detailed images of the wreck, which they later digitally merged to create the new 3D model.
The images revealed some fresh insights about the wreck. For the first time, for example, researchers spotted the Northernerâ€™s rigging, which is located roughly 60 feet away from the rest of the vessel, as Caitlin Looby reported for the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel last year.
Quick fact: Shipwrecks in the Great Lakes
Thousands of ships have sunk in the Great Lakes, including roughly 600 vessels in Lake Michigan alone.
â€œWe know less about Lake Michigan than we thought we did,â€ Russ Green, superintendent of the sanctuary, told the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel. â€œAs we push deeper into Lake Michigan, we need autonomous technology to help us figure out what's going on down there.â€
Marine archaeologists have created similar 3D replicas of other vessels, including Ernest Shackletonâ€™s Endurance. The vessel sank on November 21, 1915, after getting stuck in pack ice and has been resting on the seafloor near Antarctica ever since. In 2024, experts released a 3D model created from more than 25,000 high-resolution images captured after the iconic vessel was discovered in 2022. The Endurance scan is so detailed it even shows everyday items used by the crew, such as dining plates and a boot.
You can also explore 3D models of dozens of shipwrecks within Thunder Bay National Marine Sanctuary, a 4,300-square-mile protected area of Lake Huron.

This Mysterious Gas Cloud Spotted Around a Dead Star Is Beautifulâ€”but Astronomers Say It Shouldnâ€™t Be There
The stellar corpse is spewing star stuff, which is heating and compressing surrounding gas, resulting in a multicolored display. But itâ€™s missing a component thought to be necessary for this phenomenon
Astronomers have discovered something that, according to current knowledge, shouldnâ€™t exist. They took snapshots of a colorful yet perplexing shock wave around a white dwarf, the leftover core of a dying star.
The object has been spewing star stuff to create this colorful arc for at least 1,000 years, but itâ€™s missing something that was previously thought to be a crucial component, according to a study published January 12 in the journal Nature Astronomy.
White dwarf RXJ0528+2838 resides about 730 light-years from Earth and has a companion star orbiting it, which sends material to the dense core. In similar binary systems, the donated star material forms a disc around the white dwarf, which then funnels onto the stellar corpse. Some of the disc matter gets shot into space, creating strong outflows, and, sometimes, shock waves.
â€œA shock wave is created when fast-moving material plows into surrounding gas, suddenly compressing and heating it,â€ which also makes it colorful, study co-author Simone Scaringi, an astrophysicist at Durham University in England, tells Reutersâ€™ Will Dunham. The type seen around RXJ0528+2838 is called a bow shock, which is â€œthe curved shock front that forms when an object moves rapidly through space, similar to the wave in front of a boat moving through water,â€ he adds.
Scaringi and his colleagues first noticed a strange cloud of gas and dust, or nebula, around RXJ0528+2838 when they peered at it with the Isaac Newton Telescope in Spain. That prompted follow-up observations with the Very Large Telescope in Chile, which took snapshots of the multicolored bow shock around the white dwarf. The colors represent different elements, with red coming from hydrogen, green from nitrogen and blue from oxygen, Reuters reports.
Quick fact: The Very Large Telescope
The Very Large Telescope sits on a mountaintop in northern Chile. Itâ€™s operated by the European Southern Observatory, an astrophysics organization supported by 16 nations, and it has been observing the sky in visible-light wavelengths and beyond since 1998.
But the object was missing a surrounding disc of star material, the team found, thought to be necessary to create shock waves. â€œThe surprise that a supposedly quiet, discless system could drive such a spectacular nebula was one of those rare â€˜wowâ€™ moments,â€ Scaringi says in a statement.
Whatâ€™s more, the colorful shock wave is huge, with an estimated length about 3,800 times the distance between Earth and the sun, according to a separate statement. Analysis of its size and shape suggests the white dwarf has been spitting out material for at least a millennium.
Although the situation has puzzled the team, they suspect the white dwarfâ€™s known strong magnetic field might play a role in the enduring outflow. Computer simulations suggest the field might help the white dwarf pull material from the companion star and directly add the stolen stuff onto itself, skipping the disc step. However, the analysis found that the shock wave should last only around 600 years.
Still, the observation challenges researchersâ€™ current understanding of how stellar corpses interact with their environments. â€œIt is a powerful reminder of how incomplete our understanding of the physics powering bow shocks still is,â€ study co-author Martina Veresvarska, an astrophysicist at Durham University, says in a different statement.

articles.content:
Astronomers Find an Odd Space Cloud, Like a Galaxy Without Stars, That Could Shed Light on the Secrets of Dark Matter
Named â€œCloud-9,â€ the discovery is a new type of celestial object known as a RELHIC, that is unlike anything scientists have ever observed
Astronomers have discovered a new type of cosmic object: a gas-rich cloud about 14 million light-years away from our planet that could help illuminate the mysteries of the dark universe. Nicknamed â€œCloud-9,â€ it looks a lot like a typical galaxy, but itâ€™s missing a key ingredient.
The object appears to be starless, according to a study published in The Astrophysical Journal Letters in November and presented at a meeting of the American Astronomical Society last weekâ€”a finding that might make Cloud-9 the first known example of a RELHIC, or Reionization-Limited H I Cloud. These theoretical objects are thought to be the remnants of failed galaxies from the early universe that couldnâ€™t attract enough gas to form stars.
â€œItâ€™s basically a galaxy that wasnâ€™t,â€ Rachael Beaton, a study co-author and astronomer at the Space Telescope Science Institute, said at the meeting, per Katrina Miller at the New York Times. â€œThereâ€™s nothing like this that weâ€™ve found so far in the universe.â€
Cloud-9 was first spotted in 2023 by the Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical Telescope, a radio observatory in China. At the time, scientists werenâ€™t yet sure what they were looking at. The object appeared to completely lack stars, and subsequent observations by telescopes in the United States found the same thing. But it was still possible that ground-based observatories simply werenâ€™t strong enough to make out stars in Cloud-9, which could have been a faint dwarf galaxy.
So, astronomers turned to the Hubble Space Telescopeâ€”and again found no clear evidence of stars. Their findings only revealed a hint to one potential star, which has not been confirmed. The work â€œcertainly eliminates the possibility that [Cloud-9] is a dwarf galaxy,â€ Kristine Spekkens, an astronomer at Queenâ€™s University in Canada, who was not involved in the study, tells Jenna Ahart at Scientific American.
â€œItâ€™s clear that there is no substantial amount of stars here,â€ says Gagandeep Anand, an astronomer at the Space Telescope Science Institute, who led the work, to the New York Times.
Importantly, the study also offers insight into dark matter, the invisible force that is thought to make up 85 percent of the universeâ€™s mass.
Did you know? The dark universe
- Dark matter is invisible, because it doesnâ€™t interact with lightâ€”it doesnâ€™t absorb, emit or reflect electromagnetic waves, such as infrared, ultraviolet and visible light. But it does interact with gravity, so astronomers can see its effects on the universe.
- Dark energy is an unknown, mysterious force thatâ€™s driving the universeâ€™s accelerating expansion.
By analyzing radio waves emitted by the gas in Cloud-9, the authors found that the object has a core of neutral hydrogen with one million times the mass of our sun. Thatâ€™s not enough mass to hold the cloud together, the scientists suggest, so they calculated that Cloud-9 must be surrounded by a halo of dark matter totaling about five billion solar masses to provide gravitational support.
â€œThis cloud is a window into the dark universe,â€ says Andrew Fox, a study co-author and astronomer at the Space Telescope Science Institute, in a statement. â€œWe know from theory that most of the mass in the universe is expected to be dark matter, but itâ€™s difficult to detect this dark material because it doesnâ€™t emit light. Cloud-9 gives us a rare look at a dark matter-dominated cloud.â€
RELHICs are thought to be dark matter clouds, per the statement, making them easily outshined by nearby objects and, therefore, difficult to study. As such, researchers still have a lot to learn about Cloud-9. Spekkens tells Scientific American that the cloud doesnâ€™t have the smooth shape astronomers would expect. And by getting a better understanding of its gas distribution, she says, astronomers could paint a clearer picture of how the RELHIC formed and evolved.
If it were a lot biggerâ€”such as more than five billion times the mass of the sunâ€”it would have become a galaxy. If it were a lot smaller, the gas would have dispersed, leaving essentially nothing behind. Instead, the cloud sits in a â€œsweet spot,â€ per the statement, where it can endure as a RELHIC.
Cloud-9 isnâ€™t necessarily doomed to be a failure forever. It could still gather enough mass to become a galaxy, though scientists arenâ€™t sure how that would happen.
No matter its fate, Anand tells the New York Times that he believes more objects like Cloud-9 are out there, waiting to be discovered. â€œThis is just the first one weâ€™ve found,â€ he adds. â€œThere have got to be others like it.â€
